div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: SAAD PASHA ZAGHLOUL
div.p: The interview recently granted by the Minister of Education to a representative of the Journal du Caire" has provoked the usual outburst of indignation in the organs of | Mustapha Pasha kamnel. We are hardly surprised ; indeed we should have been amazed had the Minister succeeded for one instant of his official career in pleasing the irascible Palsu. He might, it is true, have appointed Osman Bey Ghaleb head of the Medical School, to inculcate in morals and medicine among the young galens of Kasr el-Aini ; he might have expelled all British teachers from the secondary schools : he might have requested Mustapha Pasha's friends to furnish the Khedive and Taufikiah lycées with Arabic translations of Enropean textbooks; he might have affirmed his conviction to 1,000 interviewers that the Arabic language was the noblest, the richest, the most scientific and the most up-to-date in the world ; and even then we "doubt whether he would have satisfied the complaints of the various "Standards.". The fact is that, to the ultra-nationalists, there is no middle course you are their friend or their enemy, and, mutatis mutandis, their attitude towards all | divergencies of opinion is that of the Crusaders or the early conquerors of Islam - for the "swford and bible" or "sword or , Koran," substitute the formula "the Standardor | ostracism" and you have Mustapha Pasha's standpoint clearly defined. It is an attitude. which admits of no compromise and inasmuch | as it adinits of no compromisé condemns the Pasha and his followers to lifelong opposition. It may be urged that we have neglected to answer the arguments advanced by the Nationalist writer in his criticisms of Saad Pasha Zaghloul. If we have done so it is because we are frankly disappointed by their weakness, for, though we are quite ready to admit that our sympathies are all on the side of the Minister, we are, nonetheless, anxious for discussion and actuated by the spirit which prompts the supporter of a football club to express a genuine regret at the inability of a visiting team to make any sort of resistance to his favorites.

The "Egyptian Standard" accuses the Minis. ter of vagueness and incoherence, but if we can trust our knowledge of French his declarations to Mr. Fernand Braun were remarkably clear and explicit. It is to be feared that the critic who gave his views on the interview in the "Egyptian Standard" was less conversant with French than befits a leader writer. We are the more inclined to take this view since, apart from these general accusations, the English edition of "Al Lewa" avers that Saad | Pasha expressed himself opposed on principle to universal free education ! From our reading of the French original we should say that nothing was further from the truth. The Minister opposed partial free education on the ground that it inevitably led to favoritism, while pointing out that universal free education would cost LE 3,000,000 a year and must therefore be and remain an ideal. In view of the objection of the members of the General Assembly to vote for the payment of a rate on | land for educational purposes, we consider ourselves justified in stating that public opinion is not yet sufficiently enlightened to make any general sacrifices on behalf of instruction. At present the one demand is for the reduction of taxation, and, if we are not much mistaken in our prophecies, the land and house tax will in a few years' time be the only direct tax imposed by the Government.

We, therefore, cannot congratulate the "Egyptian Standard" on the success of its criticisms, which with one exception appear to be inspired by a doubtless unintentional mis. understanding of Sand Pasha's utterances. The exception to which we refer is the criticism of the Minister's statement that teachers and textbooks must be found before teaching in Arabic can be adopted in the secondary schools. The "Standards"-French, Arabic, and English - aver that in the good old days of Ali Mubar. ek Pasha, it not earlier still, there were teachers and textbooks in abundance, and that distinguished scientists, authors,orators and what not flourished until the dark and evil days of Mr. Dunlop. Without wishing to be in any degree offensive we should like to ask the director of the three "Standards" whether, a single one of these authors or scientists attained any real eminence and acquired any reputation whatever outside his own country. We are perhaps ill-informed, but we have never heard that Egypt has in recent times produced a Koch or a Kitasato in medicine, a Hokusai in art, an Amoled or a Bert in education. The cause of the Arabic language is not assisted by the quotation of the names of gentlemen who gave instruction in it, as it would be by the evidence of the works of one author or scientist of genius, by the existence of a single prophet, honoured outside his own country.

div.head: Nile Cold Storage Co.
div.p: Sir John G, Rogers has resigned the chairmanship of the Egyptian Nile Cold Storage Company Limited and his seat on the Board as well.

div.head: World's Coaling Record
div.p: Last week at Malta his Majesty's battleship "Queen" broke the world's record for coaling, an average of 491 tons an hoor having been shipped without shore labour.

div.head: The Matarieh Disaster
div.p: The total subscriptions for the victims of the recent conflagration at Matarieh amounts to I. E 1929.132 The Finance Ministry has decided to grant LE 14,000, beside the LE. 5,000 already given in order to fill up the Jake near the town.

div.head: Brave Coastguards
div.p: On Thursday last a Russian tried to make away with himself by jumping from the quay into the East harbour. A Coastguard, who saw him, at once went to the lower ledge of the quay wall and seized the drowning man: The Constguard had nothing to hold on to and the sea came over the ledge, but he did not leave go, and aided by a second Coastguard, who came up in time they managed to save the Russian. In the man's pockets a letter was found in which he declared that nobody was to blame but himself and that he intended to make away with himself as he was tired of life. A few days previously a Greek sailor was rescued from drowning in the Western harbour by another coastguard. Thus two lives have been saved by men of the Coastguard Administration within the last few days. The rescuers have been rewarded.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTION LTD.
div.p: EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS. LTD.

We learn that the Egyptian Constructions, Ltd, have secured the contracts for two important buildings in Cairo. One of these is a large block of flats for The Anglo-Belgian Company, in Ghezireh, on a site adjoining and immediately beyond the Ghezireh Palace Hotel. "The other is for large ñew premises in Sharia Manakh for Mr. A. De Peretti, which will be Utilised on the ground floors, as Bank Offices for the Cassa di Sconto Bank and shops, and ! above as residential flats.

The Estates Chambers which this Company : has in hand for The Egyptian Estates, Ltd., first we observe being expeditiously pushed forward The comparatively love!" methods for Egypt of using a steam winch for hoisting materials, on this building, has been found to answer admirably and has more set prived a means of greatly accelerating building operations 18 ions.

We understand that Deans Building, Ghezireh Bedrane - 80 named from the fact of its being dedicated to the memory of the intel. Dean Butcher - the foundation stone off! which was laid by Lady Cromer, and the dedication ceremony conducted by the Bishop of Jerusalem is now practically completed 13 This building comprises an English school, intended principally for the children of railway employees and will have living accommodation above for the school teachers.

Other important constructions contracts jo 14 the final stages of completion, including the new wing of the San-Stefano Hotel and Casino, which will form a very important addition to this already palatial and popular summer resort

div.head: TRADE OF PALESTINE
div.p: THE ENTERPRISE OF GERMANY

The report of Mr. T. G. Freeman, Acting R British Consul at "Jerusalem, on the trade of Palestine for 1906 states that in consequence of the growth of the population by the continuous influx of Jewish immigrants from Russia and elsewhere, the importation of building materials, such as iron and steel girders for, roofing, corrugated iron sheets, tiles, planks, and cement, is increasing considerably. A very marked change is coming over Jerusalem and other towns through the substitution of girders and tiles for the time Honoured domed roofing. There is thus, says: the Consul, an opening of which German, French, and Belgian exporters have not been slow to avail themselves, and it ought to be worth the while of British exporters and steamship companies to arrange flights on the same scale as those obtaining between Hamburg or Antwerp and Jaffa The through rated by the German railways and the " Deutsche Levant Linie" enable goods to be brought from the interior of Germany and placed on the Palestine market with little addition to. the cost. "Several gas engines for motive power, with anthracite nut coal as fuel, have been imported into Palestine during the past year with such successful results. The principal advantage that! prælucer gas has over steam is economical in both fuel and water, and as, Jerusalem, like other towns in Palestine, depends on rain for its water supply, the gas engine is obviously desirable. Oil engines have of late years been re. placing the old water wheels for irrigation purposes in the 800 or 900 orange gardens in the neighbourhood of Jaffe, but if the somewhat high price of petroleum is maintained, the owners of new orchards and plantations will, no doubt, adopt gas instead of oil engines.

div.head: HONOUR TO LORD CROMER
div.p: SOCIETY OF ARTS

London, Friday. The Society of Arts with the approval of its President the Prince of Wales has awarded the Albert medal of the society for the current year to Lord Cromer "in recognition of preeminent public service in Egypt, where he has imparted security to the relations of Britain with the East, and has established justice, restored order, and prosperity, and by his initiation of great works has opened up new fields for enterprise.

div.head: To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: Sir, "The prosperity of the Alexandria Sporting Club is of interest to most of the leading members of European and native society elicits pity, and I therefore am writing this letter at the suggestion of a number of members of the club to ventiláte a very legitimate grievance, which is gradually becoming a public scandal. I refer to the increasing patronage of the races by numbers | of undesirable women. If this sort of thing is allowed to go by much longer I know of any ladies who will abstain from attending the races. It youll be an easy matter to exercise some supervision in this respect. A few years ago the haces were free from this objectionable class Spectator but now every mee meeting seems to attract more and more persons of this stain
Truly Yours,
PATERFAMILIAS.
May 31st.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO
div.p: FESTA DELLO STATUTO

C'est demain à 5 h. après-midi que sera elébré la grande Fête Nationale Italienne : nous rappelonsqu'à cette occasion sera inangnrée la nouvelle Musique "Alessandro Lamar: mora," dont on nous dit le plus grand bien. Le programme de l'orchestre Bracale sera composé de morceaux choisis dans le grand répertoir Italien et le Jeune ténor Mr. Martire se fera entendre dans plosieurs romances. Cette fête prendra on caractère tout à fait officiel, par soite de la présence de Mr. le Consul d'Italie, le Marquis de Soragna. | A 10 K. du matin grand concert symphonique par l'orchestre Bracale. | Nous sommes informés que, vu l'énorme succès obtenu jeudi dernier par A. Serato, la direction da Casino organise un 2me concert pour jeudi prochain avec le concours du célèbre violoniste, dans un programme tout à fait nogveau.

div.head: EGYPTS FREEDOM
div.p: DEMAND FOR PARLIAMENT
London, Friday.

Sir Walter Mieville writing in the "Nineteenth Century" on Britain's task in Egypt, says "If Egypt really wishes to have its own constitution it must gain its liberation by means of intellectual progress. But for the time being the demand for a parliament seems futile and premature. It will be time enough to seriously consider this grave question when really representative Egyptians and not a noisy faction present a reasoned petition for extended powers of self-government.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: Yesterday the Khedive attended midday prayers at the mosque of Sidi Boushr. His Highness will preside over the Council of Ministers to be held to morrow at Ras-el-Tin Palace
Count von Wachmeister, Swedish Diplomatic "Agent, was received by the Khedive this morning when he presented his credentials to his Highness. The following speeches were exchanged :--

Monseigneur, Le roi, mon Auguste Souverain, ayant bien voulu me nommer Consul Général de Suède en Egypte, j'ai l'honneur de remettre à votre Altesse les lettres qui accréditent en cette qualité auprès d'Elle

Rien ne pouvait m'être plus agréable que cette inission d'exprimer ici les voeux que Sa Majesté, mon Auguste Souverain, a toujours formé pour le bonneur de Votre Altesse et pour la prospérité de cette admirable pays, qui a de tout temps accordé à mes compatriotes tant d'hospitalité.

Mes efforts tendront à travailler au développement de tous les intérêts Suédois, en Egypte et à rendre de plus en plus étroits les liens d'amitié si heureusement établis entre les deux pays. Pour l'accomplissement de cette tâche, j'ose compter sur la Haute Bienveillance de Votre Altesse ainsi que sur l'appni de Son Gouvernement The Khedive replied Monsieur le Consul Général, Je reçois avec plaisir les lettres qui vous accréditent en qualité de Consul Général de Suède en Egypte et Je remercie vivement Sa Majesté le Roi, Votre Auguste Souverain, des yeux qu'il a toujours daigné foriner pour l'Egypte et pour moi.

Heureux de vous entendre me parler comme vous le faites de mon pays et de ce qui est l'objet de votre mission,' Je me plais à vous assurer, Monsieur le Consul Général, que vous | trouverez auprès de mon Gouvernement tont l'appui que vous pouvez désirer dans l'accomplissemerit de votre tâche.
Je saisis en même temps cette ocasion pour vous prier de transmettre à Sa Majesté l'exPressiour tes veux sincères que je formie égale
That pour son bonheur et la prospérité de la Sugle,

div.head: THE WESTERN BORDER
div.p: SURVEY WORK BEGUN

That Byptian Government has decided to undertake a survey of the north western Court district of the country from Mex onwards. The work of survey has already been started and the superintendence of the enterprise has | been entrusted to Mr. Montagu.of the Survey Department. It is probable that the survey 1 will be made as far as the frontier. As the Government has also began constructing | a line of telegraphs to Mersa Matrouh, it is to be presumed that this hitherto neglected part of the country will at last evoke some interest. The development of the Mariout railway by the Khedive has given a great impetus to the district from | Max to Ras el Debba, the present terminus of the line. The organisation of the Coast Guards Administration in establishing posts along the east during the last few years has also had a civilising effect. The cultivation of barley, etc.is being extended and if wells were sunk in likely localities, the agricultural resources might be still further developed. It will be interesting to see how much land is under cultivation when the survey has been carried out.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The leave of Saba Pasha, the Postmaster General, begins to-day. Upon the expiration of his Excellency's leave on the 15th September he will definitely retire from the service. During the time Saba Pasha is on leave Borton Bey will act as Postmaster General.
The banquet to be given by the Swiss colony in honour of Dr. Schiess? 70th birthday anniversary is to take place this evening at a quarter past eight.
Mr. Lang Anderson has joined the local board of the United Egyptian Lands Limited in succession to the late Mr. Sydney Carver.

James Kynaston Edwards Verschoyle, C.M.G., of Cairo, Inspector-General of Irrigation in Lower Egypt, who died on the 17th March last aged 49 years, son of the late Canon Richard Verschoyle, of Tallydonnell, Donegal, rector of Derryvalley), left estate in the United Kingdom valued at £8,303 gross, of which £7,986 is net personal. Probate of this will has been granted to Mrs. Edith 1 Verschoyle, of 23 Courtfield"Gardens, London, daughter of Mr. Matthew Wilson Armour, of Liverpool

div.head: THE FINANCIAL CRISIS
div.p: HEAVY DEPRECIATIONS

There has of late been a number of remarkable calculations as to the depreciation in Egyptian shares, which has taken place during the last few months. There is the same tale to tell at home and according to the "Bankers' Magazine, " the depreciation in 387 repreşentative securities taken for comparison between April 20and May 21, amounted to £87,159,000 while since the beginning of the year it comes to no less than £185,000,000. Since one of the 1 principal influences supposed to have contribu|ted to the decline in stocks at the end of last year-viz., dear money, has largely disappeared, the extreme depression is the more remarkable. "Of the total decline since the beginning of the year," says the magazine, "American railroad securities are responsible for no less than £106,000,000, and no doubt the severe collapse in that department has had much to do with the fall in the other direction, The Daily Telegraph" in commenting on these facts observes :

"Unfortunately, however, there have also e been other influences operating, which have affected markets, which might otherwise have been expected to benefit by any distrust in the speculative descriptions. Notwithstanding excellent traffic returns, English railways show a fc further serious decline, and, in fact, it may be b said that nearly all first class British Government securities, including Consols, have led / h the downward movement during the pasta month The campaign on the part of the Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants, with its threatened strike later in the year, f has been primarily responsible for the fall in English rails, but, looking at the matter in more broadly, it may be said that the Socialistic tendencies, which receive such favour at the hands of the present Government, are mainly responsible for the complete lack of confidence on the part of investors in home securities."

These are the views of a journal which is not in the Imbit of exaggerating or writing loosely, and they therefore deserve notice. These observations convey their lesson for Egypt. "If this can be done in the green tree what can be done in the dry."

Is it to be wondered that Egyptian securities should have shrunk 15,000,000 in a country far less adapted to socialistic propaganda than Egypt. The effect has been great. Would be nationalists cannot injure their country more than by proposing wild schemes of self Government which will depress further an already weak market.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM
div.p: THE RUSH TO ENGLAND
(From "Al Watan")

Several gentlemen of notoriety or position among Egyptians are going to England this year. It appears that the decision of Saad Pashai | Zaghloul, the Minister of Public Instruction, to visit the shores of Albion this year has resulted in similar decisions elsewhere. We hear now that Sheikh Ali Youssef of AlMoayyed, Mustafa Pasha Kamel of 'Al-Lewa, and others are going to England too. Theli decision of these journalists and Nationalist agitators to follow Saad Pasha to London sounds like a boyish trick of the ridiculous species. Yet it is a fact that the Nationalists attribute political designs to the Minister and are decided upon stultifying his efforts where ever he goes and whatever he may say or do He is a Cromerite, a creation of the former | pro-consul whom they call the greatest enemy of their race and their faith. Surely he must be going to consult Lord Cromer on new devices for destroying the glorious edifice of Nation alist faith. He ought to be followed and contradicted whenever he tries to make a statement about Egypt before an English audience !

Bravo ! But we had been told that England does not count for much in the game. Is it because a Radical Ministry now rules in England that these Nationalist leaders of Pan Islamism try to take England now by storm 1: If that is their view of the case we can only refer them to India and draw their attention to the attitude of that most liberal of Ministers, Mr. J. Morley. His firmness in the cases of risk and emergency may act as some antidote to their illusions and their dreams.

div.head: ROYAL DUBLIN FUSILIERS
OFFICER'S SUDDEN DEATH
div.p: Yesterday afternoon, Lentenant A. de B. W. W. Bradford, 2nd Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, died with startling wilderness at Cork. The deceased officer was attending an examination of officers for promotion, at Cork Barracks, at the time. At the inquest last night, a lieutenant of the Royal Field Artillery said he had spent the last two days with deceased, who seemed in perfect health. He was, however, very anxious about his examination and l. its possible result. After lunching at the hotel yesterday they set out on their return to the examination room. After they had gone a short distance deceased complained of feeling La little fagged, and dropped his head. He appeared to recover, but after they had proceeded | a little further, witness thought he was not improving and he was about to take him back to the hotel when he suddenly collapsed. He f was removed to the hotel where he died in a few minutes without saying anything. Medical evidence showed that death was due to hemorrhage of the brain and a verdict in accordance was returned.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HARBOUR
div.p: PROGRESS OF THE WORKS
THE GREAT PASS
The work on the Great Pass into Alexandria | Harbour is proceeding in a most satisfactory manner. This pass is twice the width of the Boghaz | Pass, which was only three hundred feet wide.

It is also five feet deeper than the Boghaz Pass. The channel when finished and lighted will facilitate the entry and exit of ships and ti is all that could be desired for the existing size of vessels.

The construction of the Great Pass has been no easy matter, the site being entirely exposed to the wind and sea. The quantity already dredged amounts to about seven hundred thousand cubic metres odd. Al this 10 was excavated without blasting and could only si have been done by such efficient dredgers as G the two lent by the British Admiralty to the Egyptian Government. One of the dredgers lent by the Admiralty, which has been employ P led on this pass, is leaving shortly for England.

The new lighthouse now being built at Mext is being rapidly constructed and should be ready when the pass is opened. One of the breakwaters for the new harbour for barges at Ras-el-Tins is already: laid and being squared up on the top. The second breakwater will be commenced shortly. This harbour will be amply sufficient to accommodate all the lighters in the port and thus will | relieve the congestion now existing in the Careening Basin, where the small fruit vessels from Greece And Turkey land their cargoes.

The extension of the breakwater is advancing very favourably, and of late owing to the remarkably calm weather in May most of the bottom rubble has been placed in position. The concrete blocks reaching above the water, with their requisite quantity of backing, have been placed to the extent of about one hundred and forty metres. This portion, however, is principally in shallow water and consequently the work here has advanced far quicker than the rest of the work is likely to do, 'which has to be constructed in deep water. | It is probable that the remaining Admiralty I. dredger when the pass is finished will be utilised to dredge out the shoal on the NorthEast side of the breakwater and other shallow parts of the harbour. This latter enterprise.is absolutely necessary on account of the Great Pass adinitting ships of deeper draught into the port: at present 500 acres of perfectly land-1 locked anchorage is useless for any but shipping vessels of slight draught. The amount of soil : I to be removed is about 3,600,000 cubic metres.

If this shoal were dredged, Alexandria would | become one of the finest, if not the very finest, harbour in the Mediterranean. The construction of the timber quays is making considerable headway, but every effort has necessarily up to now been concentrated in the breakwater extension, in order to take advantage of the fine weather. At the same time ballasting, etc.is progressing on the site : of the timber quays.

The programme now in course of completion will be finished in 1909. The tonnage of goods imported and exported at Alexandria in 1900 was 2,394,000. In 1905, it was 3,450,000, and in 1906, 3,660,000. Allowing the very moderate | annual increase of 10 per cent in tonnage, it will amount to 4,880,000 tons in 1909. Byl that time, 8,000 metres of berthing will be completed, or 1 metre to, 604 tons of goods. Admiral Sir R. M. Blomfield and Mr. Malaval, the distinguished engineer of the Port of Alexandria, paid a visit in the course of last summer to the principal commercial ports of Great Britain and the Continent, with a view to the introduction of such changes as might seem most suitable to Alexandrian require. ments. Amongst other interesting information, they ascertained that the proportion of berth. ing to tonnage was, at Trieste, 1 metre to 281 tons; at Hamburg, 1 metre to 368 tons; at Marseilles, 1 metre to 380 tons; at Havre, 1 metre to 233 tons ; at Liverpool, 1 metre to 274 tons pat Manchester, 1 metre to 402 tons; and at Glasgow, 1 metre to 581 tons; and that at all these ports additional quays were in course of construction. The only port with a larger proportion of tonnage per metre' of quay than Alexandria is Antwerp, which has 1 metre toʻ719 tons; but a large proportion of the goods brought to that port goes by water | to the interior of Belgium and Germany, moreover, it appears that an extension of no less than 45,000 metres of quay has been commenced at Antwerp. Under these circumstances, when the programme now being carried out is completed, further works will have to be undertaken. It may perhaps he that the completion of the harbour works at Port Said - will to some extent relieve the congestion at Alexandria ; although my personal belief is that the trade of the country is growing to such an extent that no action taken at Port Said will materially affect Alexandrian requirements.

div.head: COMPLAINT FROM DUEM
div.p: The Duem merchants complain that proper accommodation is not provided for them in order to send their goods by the Government steamers up the Nile. These steamers arrive at Duem and leave at irregular hours and very | often after the merchants have had their packages carried to the landing-place at night, they are refused shipment, and have to take 1 them back to town. They desire to call the attention of the Steamers and Boats Department to this matter, and request that better | arrangements may be made.

div.head: WALKER AND MEIMARACHI LIMITED
div.p: Sir- In view of certain misleading statements which have appeared in various Egyptian newspapers, I am instructed by my Directors to make public the following frete with regard to the . Extraordinary General Meeting of the above Company, which should have been held in London on the isth inst.
The Board of Directors of the Company at present consists of six members, three of whoan (including the Chairman) are resident has resulted in Egypt, and three in London.
For a long time past the dual adıninistra tion has proved unsatisfactory, and latterly in a complete "impasse".

In March last a number of shareholders, representing some 35,000 shares, served on the Board a Requisition calling upon them to convene an Extraordinary General Meeting of the Company to be held in London for the purpose of replacing two of the London Directors reside in Egypt, Mr. George Royle and Colonel Gordon, C.B. being proposed to fill the vacancies.

As the Company's Articles of Association provide that a Requisition must be lodged at the Company's Registered Office, the Requisition, after being duly noted by the Board in Cairo who decided that the Meeting should be held as required, was forwarded to the Registered Office of the Company in London, and the duty of convening the Meeting thus devolved on the London Directors.

The London Directors, being determined to maintain their attitude, had two courses open to them : either to convene a Meeting in accordance with the Requisition, or to ignore the Requisition, in which latter case the shareholders themselves would have been entitled to convene the Meeting on the expiry of 21 days from the date of service of the Requisition.
They elected to convene the Meeting, and after an exchange of telegrams, 'the 13th May was finally fixed as the date of the Meeting, on the request of the Cairo Directors.
On the 28th April an alternative proposal was submitted to the Board in Cairo, of a nature much more acceptable to the London Directors than the original project embodied in the Requisition.
This alternative proposal was that the number of Directors should be increased to nine, by the election of three new Directors, Messrs. George Royle, Colonel Gordon, C.B., and Dr. Herbert Milton.

This proposal was unanimously approved by the Cairo Directors, and a telegram was immediately sent to the London Directors by the Chairman that the Requisition would be with drawn, and requesting them to attend a Meeting of the Board in Cairo on the 6th May to consider the new proposal, and, if thought fit, convene a General Meeting to vote on the same.

The only reply made to this by the London Directors was that unless both proposals were unconditionally withdrawn the original programme would be proceeded with, and that in the absence of a reply from Cairo by the following "Thursday evening, the 2nd May, the notice convening the. Meeting would be issued the next morning, Friday.

To this the Cairo Directors made no reply, thus clearly indicating that the Meeting should be proceeded with on the original lines. | All preparations were made on this side: knofficial notices were published that the Meeting would be held in London on the 13th May; Shareholders deposited their shares in the one Bank designated by the London Directors, and executed proxies in favour of the Chairman, Mr. Carton de Wiart, whom they had chosen to represent them, and who sailed for London on the 6th May specially to attend the Meeting 1. On his arrival in London, Mr. Carton de Wiart was met by his representative with the information that the London Directors had failed to convene the Meeting.

The position is therefore that the London Directors failed to convene the Meeting after having undertaken to do so, and after having even issued to certain European Shareholders tickets of admission to "The Extraordinary General Meeting to be held on the 13th May." No intimation of any kind was given to the Egyptian Directors. of Shareholders that the Meeting might not be held, though such intimation would have spared the expense and inconvenience of a useless journey to London by the Chairman.

The Shareholders have now announced their intention of serving a second Requisition for a Meeting to be held early in July, at which it is anticipated not only that a very large number of Egyptian Shareholders will be represented, but that their views will by strongly. supported by European Shareholders. The Shareholders will probably shortly be invited to attend an informal Meeting to receive a detailed statement of what has passed in London, and be informed of the procedure to be followed in order to hold a Meeting in July.
I am, Sir,
Yours faithfully,
G. W. BENNETT.
Secretary for Egypt
WALKER & MEIMARACHI LTD.

div.head:
TROUBLES OF GOVERNMENT
UNFULFILLED PROMISES
PROTESTS OF PARTIES

div.p: The difficulties of the Government were exemplified by two meetings held yesterday evening. The Labour party passed resolutions urging the Government to employ the Autumn session for the purpose of carrying a Miners' Eight Hours Day Bill and other harbour measures.

Sixty Non-conformišt members of Parliament adopted a sternly worded resolution with reference to the delay in the fulfilment of the Government's education promises. The appeals of the Government delegates for a more moderate resolution led to angry speeches. The Temperance party is equally insistent upon licensing reform.
There are also signs of recrudescence of agrarian troubles in Ireland." (Renter)
At Houston (Texas) storms and cloudbursts occurred throughout the night cover ing the country with water. Railroads have been obstructed and houses wrecked. (Reuter)
The steamer Boniface from "Galveston for Liverpool has arrived here with her cargo of cotton on fire since Sunday. (Reuter)
30,000 Chinese are in revolt 40 miles to the south of Amoy. The Viceroy of Fuchou is sending 8,000 troops. The disaffection is spreading. Warships are expected. (Reuter)
Engine drivers have decisively voted against going on strike, nevertheless the miners are determined to maintain their attitude. (R)
The Bill for the establishment of a Criminal 1! Appeal Court unanimously passed the second! reading.
(Reuter)
The British journalists witnessed the spring parade at Potsdam. They heartily cheered the Emperor who acknowledged the greeting. (R.)
At the conclusion of an interview the Emperor heartily welcomed the English journalists.
(Havas)
The chamber has approved the remission of class 1904 to September.
(Havas)
King Haakon, passing the frontier, exchanged cordial telegrams with Mr. Palliéres. (Havas)

div.head: THE PORT OF ALEXANDRIA
div.p: A TRAVELLERS COMPLAINT
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir,-On May 18th I reached Alexandria from Port Said, by the steamship Sallzburg" of the Austrian Lloyd Line, at about 2 p.m., and departed by the "Semiramis" of the same line about three and a half hours later. More than two hours of my stay were passed in securing what was called a health i certificate from the authorities at the custom house, a short distance away from the two steamers. At the two windows, where papers allowing us to reach the examining physician were secured, there was great disorder, it being a matter of strength and meanness as to who should be first waited upon; still there seemed to be an abundant supply of policemen standing around. During the scramble for said papers a pickpocket relieved me of about one hundred francs.

When we were finally admitted to the presence of the physician, he proceeded to examine us in a manner much more like an officer searching our persons for concealer A weapons or contraband goods, than like an examining health officer. No one witnessing the proceeding could have had so little sense | as to regard it as anything more than a big farce. One traveller expressed his contempt for the whole procedure by saying that we were required to sign a paper certifying that we had no dirty clothes in our baggage.

After I had secured the so-called health certificate, I started to walk back to the steamer by the way I had come. The attending policeman who should have protected me from being robbed, snatched my certificate from my hand and thrust it into his pocket. This was to compel me to take a boat at an extortionate price, when it would require my compassing three times the distance required in walking. I failed to learn that any other passenger reached the steamer from the sea side, and my so going abroad seemed to raise the suspicion that I was trying to do so clandestinely until I produced my valuable (1) certificate. It seems quite evident that the said policeman was working in conspiracy with the boatmen.

Now, I am not protesting against the use of due precautions in protecting the health of the people in any and all lands, but I would enter a vigorous protest against any such fareical and disorderly proceeding as that I witnessed at the Alexandria custom house, on May 18th. I do not know who are responsible for such proceedings, but I do know that it is an entourage upon the travelling public, for the responsible parties to fail to provide proper facilities and protection in carrying out the requirements of the law. I feel that you, sir, as the editor of the "Gazette," for the sake of the reputation of your fair city, and for the sake of all Egypt, should call attention to the abuses of which I here complain.

As to myself, I will say that I am an American citizen, at present residing in Jerusalemu, that I am a clergymen in good standing in the Methodist church, and can produce abundant testimonials as to my good character. I expect to be absent from Jerusalem for some months, but anything addressed there to me will be forwarded to me.
P. C. STANTON.
On Board the "Semiramis."

div.head: CAESAR'S CAMP
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" Sir:--

Referring to "Duleamara's" letter of the 29th inst, I beg to state that "Unsatisfied" had not the slightest intention of indulging or wedging a polemical controversy in your valuable columns. He simply wished to benefit humanity in general by bringing to the notice of the public an abnormal state of matters. My informant, although rather stern in business matters, enjoys a joke as much as another and occasionally indulges in the humourous "freak" of nature when circumstances warrant his doing 50. Right you are, sweet "Dulcamara" ; your very "nom de plume" breathes euphony. Yes, if I remember well, Sarah Bernhardt was carried off the rails, and if I remember rightly, she had to act in a tragedy instead of a comedy, but these considerations de really frivolous when one considers that she actually scored and realised her aim, i.e., held her appointment and snapped her fingers in the face of the railway authorities, and gloriously overcame adverse circumstances. Such, however, was not the case of my practical friend who had solid business to attend to and who was not bent on an errand to amuse or to emotion the public. My friend, however, did not trudge into town "la suffragette"; he got his tram and bene. fitted many of the "suffering" Campo-Onesarites by his attitude towards the A.R.Co. and instead of annihilating himself, remains in life to proclaim and maintain the rights of the people.
Yours truly,
UNSATISFIED.
Alexandria, May 31st 1907.

According to an American paper, the editor of the "Rolette County Examiner" has had A tussle, with a bear on exhibition in the town, and has since explained that, though bruin got the worst of it, he did not really intend to hurt the bear. "This shows," says our contemporary, that it is best to let editors alone." On the other hand, it might have shown that it is better for editors to leave bears alone.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: CRICKET
LADIES v. GENTLEMEN

On Friday afternoon, a team of eleven Alex. andria ladies mode an excellent effort to beat mere man at his own sport of cricket, and though they failed they gave a very good exhibition. The odds were in the ladies' favour, the usual, though somewhat extravagant, concessions being made. The gentlemen of course fielded, bowled and batted left-handed and the bat was replaced by the broomstick." Skirts before wicket did not count out, but on the contrary proved a valuable help to the wearers and run-outs were converted into no balls.

The ladies took first knock and made a disastrous start, the first five "outs" only compiling 6, 3 of whiệh were off Miss Moss's bat and the other 3 from Miss Leese. Miss Wraxall, however, came to the rescue and compiled a useful 10, but two ducks and at two were next to be recorded. Miss Gentilli strengthened the tail which wagged far more successfully than the head, and by excellent all-round-the-wicket play put together 28, Miss Koole who partnered her for the last wicket, being not out for four, useful addition to the ladies total was the wide and very wide, the former counting the usual I and the latter 2. The dismissal of the ladies was due in the main to Mr. Kerr, Mr. Greig, Mr. Moss, and Mr. Harkness, the last of whom, with somewhat doubtful galanterie, caught out seven players. Fielding with the right hand counted one run to the batter. The fielding of the gentlemen was very keen and | runs were hard to get, though not a few were lost by hesitation. 1 On taking the field the ladies worked hard and did excellently, their principal fault being lack of combination, while they might have done better by changing over when the bowling changed ends. Miss Moss fielded brilliantly and in the long field should soon become a Denton Tor Tydlesley with some coaching, and Miss Koole's ground work was very neat. The returns might have been straighter, but the ladies can congratulate themselves on having mulled fewer catches than their opponents, though it must be said that the latters' offers were not very liberal In commenting upon the general style of play we might mention that heaps of material, for the invention of new strokes was offered by both sides. Several of the gentlemen found a | peculiar mowing stroke of great use, and there were one or two leg glances from the ladies, which, though difficult of description, might be cultivated by our more serious players.
Mr. Hilary Moss, who organised the match, and Miss Moss were "at home," and tea and refreshments were served during the afternoon.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton

La semaine qui vient de finir et que nous Huns passer en revue, se trouve encore écour tée l'un jour, à la suite de la suspension d'affaires que nous avons éue samedi dernier, mais cela n'empêche pas qu'elle a été non pas relativement mais réellement intéressante, ne fut ce qu'à la suite du revirement soudain qui s'est produit depuis hier et qui a modifié du tout au tout la terrue et la tendance du marché.

Et de fait, au début et pendant trois jours consécutifs cela n'a été qu'une série, pour ainsi dire, de séances inactives, faibles et en baisse au point que l'on en était arrivé à se demander, pendant la matinée de Mercredi, s'il n'y avait, après tout, pas de limite à ces offres en Juillet, qui ne cessaient pas et qui abimnient tout. Certes, nous aurions inauvaise grâce, personnellement, de nous plaindre d'avoir vu nos idées se réalisêr presque complètement; mais comme en fin de compte tout est relatif, nous avonons ne pas avoir été des moins surpris à voir la mauvaise tournure que prenaient les choses à un moment donné: il y avait presque de la frayeur de la part de la spéculation, qui ne tenait plus compte de la situation de l'amé. cain et qui avait fini par ne prendre en considération que les pronostics de retour au beau temps et, comme conséquence naturelle, l'imminence de la réaction.

Fort heureusement, non seulement pour les haussiers, mais pour la place en général, avec toutes ces difficultés financières dont nous jouissons depuis quelqne temps, les prédictions américaines ne sont pas réalisées et avec l'accentuation de la hausse que New Orleans nous a envoyée jeudi matin, une volte face a commencé à se dessiner. De plus, la demande pour les égyptiens de la part de la filature, qui n'a pu rester insensible à la hausse de l'Américain, s'étant tont à coup réveillée, surtout pour les cotons ancienne récolte, le marché s'est trouvé, tout à coup favorisé de divers éléments de hausse, et, comme cela devait être le cas, nos détenteurs de contrats. en ont profité pour pousser les cours à leur plus grand profit,

Le mouvement, cette fois, avait donc de bonnes et solides bases et s'il a en un défaut, c'est d'avoir été plutot précipité, mais la rapidité de la reprise peut parfaitement bien s'ex pliquer par l'exagération de la baisse que nous avions ene et qui aurait été admissible à la veille de l'éch/ance Juillet, mais qui était prématurée en ce moment-ei.

Pour résumer maintenant les fluctuations enregistrées pendant la semaine, nous dirons que le minimuin pratiqué a été de 18 2132 pour le Juillet et de 18 15/16 pour le No. vembre, soit respectivemegt 9/16 et 11/32 de baisse sur la cloture de vendredi dernier, et que le inaximum, auquel nous avodis aussi clo turé, a été 19 1/2 et 19 19/32, soit une reprise totale de 27/32 et 11/16, on en d'autres termes hansse acquise depuis vendredi passé de 9/32 pour la récolte actuelle et 11/32 pour la prochaine. Le résultat n'est donc pas mauvais, surtout que la tendence semble favorable, souf le cas où le prochain rapport du Burean d'Agri. culture de Washington nous servirait, d'une façon inattendue, une de ces surprises sur les. quelles le parti baissier en Amérique parait compter, ou, pour mieux dire, dans les puelles, il semble espérer,

Maintenant, pour ce qui est de l'avenir, il n'est pas aisé de philosopher: Comme éléments contraires à la hausse nous avons la situation financière locale et la non existence d'un decouvert sérieux, car tous les casseurs des prix ont fini par se racheter aujourd'hui. Par contre, le pour résiderait dans la continuation de la demande de la part de la filature et dans le maintien des cours de l'Américain qui la favoriserait, le cas échéant, Nous dépendons donc en definitive de l'Amérique et de son prochain rapport, et par conséquent, il n'est pas étonnant de voir notre place niontrer, non seulement de la nervosité, mais mêine de l'anxiété dans son attente du rapport en question. . D'aillenrs, nous ne sommes pas les seuls à regardler de ce côté-là, car le succès ou le fiasco des partis en lutte en Amérique dépendent. aussi de ce que le Bureau nous dira au sujet de l'acrénge et de la condition de la plante En attendant, pour ce qui est le ces deux points, nous dirons que les pronosts vont de 68 à 38, de quoi offrir du choix à tout le monde, et que l'on prétend que l'opinion a changé en ce qni concerne l'étendue ensemencée que de 35 inillions d'acres, on réduit aujourd'hui à 31 millions! Price et son parti sont à la baisse monis ils se tiennent tranquilles, attendant l'occasion propice pour commencer leurs manouvres. Eventuellement, ils auraient pour eux la cherté des blés à la suite de la non Wursite des récoltes d'Amérique et de Roumane; mais, l'effet de ceci ne pourrait se faire sentir qu'nt la longue

Pour revenir et en fuir avec le marché des montrats, nous dirons que l'activité a fini par etre såtiffaisante et que les opérations du commerce ne sont pas restées confinées aux achats en Juillet, mais qu'elles ont aussi porté sur le Novembre

Ce dernier point ne doit pas nous surprentre d'ailleurs, étant donné que malgré tout, soit la cherté du prix et la possibilité d'une bonne récolte américaine comine qualité, la filature a' montré beaucoup d'intérêt pour la nouvelle fécolte, et peut-être même d'une façon route particulière pour les provenances Haute-, Erypte livraison Septembre. • Unentre point intéressant à relever est la diminution du report de Juillet à Novembre: nous étions à 1/4 de tallari; aujourd'hui il n'y & plus que 3/32 et pour peu que la filature continue à nous demander da rapproche, poute différence pourrait disparaitre et peut etre, de report se changer en déport.
Seulement, pour tout ce que nous venons de dire, il nous faudrait un rapport de Washington

div.head: Slaves to Spring Catarrh Restored to Health by Pe-ru-na.
div.p: SPRING THE TIME TO CURE CARARRH.

div.head: Pe-ru-na invigorates Mind and Body.
div.p: Hon. Wm. G. Hunter, Ex-member North Carolina Legislature, writes from the Census Office Building, Washington, D. C., as follows:
"The greatest family medicine ever discovered, In my opinion, which comes from experience as well as observation, la Peruna.

"The most common sanction to humankind is a bad cold. Peruna drives it out of doors, wards off catarrh, invigorates and gives fresh strength to mind and body. I give Peruna my unqualified endorsement."—Wm. G. Hunter.

div.head: Takes Pe-ru-na Every Spring.
div.p: Miss Tilly Marx, 421 14th St., Milwaukee, Wis, writes :
"I am pleased to endorse Peruna, as I found it very efficient in ridding my system of a severe cold and catarrhal trouble, after I had tried many other remedies without getting relief.

"I took Peruna for two weeks, when I was much better, and in two weeks more I was entirely rid of the cold and catarrh. I shall take it every spring as a tonic, as I found that it made me much better in every wey." ––Tilly Marx.
Miss Lydia Herziger, Grand Recorder of American Daughters of Independence, writes from Mronah, Wis., as follows :
"I have used Peruna now for four years, each Spring and Fall, and it keeps me perfectly well and strong.
"I am able to continue working and do not have to take a three months' rest, as I used to do every year. This is a great comfort to me, as I was not able to afford such a long rest.
"I find that it is great preventative for colds and coughs and soon rids the system of all discase and is an admirable medicine. I can honestly endorse it." ––Lydia Herxiger.
Spring Catarrh.
Almost every one has come to believe that spring is a season that brings derangements of the body dependent on blood impurities.
This belief is an old one, is nearly universal, and has arisen, not as the result of the teachings of the medical fraternity, but has been learned in the bitter school of experience.
Nervous Depression.
Depression of the nervous system at the approach of spring is a fertile source of blood impurities.
There are general lassitude, dull, heavy tired feelings, with poor appetite, and sometimes loss of sleep.
The Tired Feeling.
That tired feeling, which is the natural result of the depressing effect of warm weather immediately after the invigorating cold of winter, quickly disappears when Peruna is taken.
The Proper Remedy.

Peruna meets every indication and proves itself to be perfectly adapted to all their varied peculiarities. Peruna invigorates the system, rejuvenates the feelings, restores the normal appetite and procures regular sleep.
Do Not Delay.

Get a bottle of Peruna when the first languid feelings make themselves apparent in the spring. Take it according to the directions on the bottle. Continue this treatment through the first months of spring.
This course of treatment is no experiment; It is as positive in its results as any fact of science can be.
A Spring Tonis.

Almost everybody needs a tonic in the spring. Something to brace the nerves, invigorate the brain, and cleanse the blood. That Peruna will do this is beyond all question. Everyone who has tried it has had the same experience as Mrs. Winnifred Power, an artist, who, in a recent letter from 246 7th St., Portland, Ore., says:

p.hi: "I am pleased to speak a good word for Peruna, as I found it an excellent tonic and spring medicine and very effective in ridding the system of cold and catarrh.

div.p: "About two years ago my system was all ran down in the spring and I thought I would try and see if Peruna would be of any assistance in bringing back my health and strength.
"I found that it was splendid and all the medicine that I needed. In a little over a month I was well and did not need to take any more medicine.
"I shall recommend it to every one in need of a tonic, and know that I have only to take a few doses of Peruna when I take a cold and I will soon be over it." —Winnifred Power.
Nature's Assistance.
Spring is the best time to treat catarrh. Nature renews herself every spring. The system is rejuvenated by spring weather. This renders medicine more effective.
A short course of Peruna, assisted by the balmy air of spring, will cure old, stubborn cases of catarrh that have resisted treatment for years.
A Word of Advice.
To those who have been afflicted with chronic catarrh we wish to say that the spring season affords yon a splendid opportunity to get rid of your disease.
It may be you have been afflicted for several years; you may have tried different remedies. Perhaps you have become discouraged.
Now is Your Opportunity.
This failure was during ths winter months. But now is your opportunity. Nature comes to your assistance at this season.
Just help her a little and she will bring you out of the quagmire in which you have been floundering so long. Give Nature a little assistance lost her struggles be in vain.
A Typical Case.
Geo. M. Fillmore, late 1st Lieut. 3rd U.S. Artillery, writes from 900 L St., N. W., Washington, D. C., as follows :
"I brought forward from winter into spring a sickening case of catarrh which was making existence miserable for me, until I was induced to try a bottle of Peruna.

"An immediate improvement gave me hope, if not relief. I kept up taking Peruna and it has so strengthened and relieved me that I am now confident of a cure. I heartily endorse Peruna for catarrhal affections and as a tonic for their weakening effects."—Geo. M. Fillmore.

p.hi: A short course of Peruna now will be just in time. During the month of April you will find the strategic time to rid yourself of chronic catarrh, one of tha most persistent, stubborn diseases in the whole list of human aliments.

div.p: After you have tried it you will say Peruna is positively the best spring medicine you have ever used.
A great many years of extensive trials of this remedy in this class of derangements have demonstrated that there are no failures.
Thousands of Testimonials.
Thousands of cases might be quoted in which Peruna has rescued people from the ravages of spring catarrh, and put them on a good, solid foundation of health.

We can give our readers only a slight glimpse of the vast array of unsolicited endorsements Dr. Hartman is constantly receiving. No other physician in the world has received such a volume of enthusiastic letters of thanks.

If you do not derive prompt and satisfactory results from the use of Peruna, write at once to Dr. Hartman, giving a full statement of your case and he will be pleased to give you his value his advice gratis.
Address Dr. Hartman, President of The Hartman Sanitarium, Columbus, Ohio. All correspondence hold strictly confidental.

En attendant, chez nous et pour ce qui regarde la récolte, les choses inarchent à sou

hait. Le résumé de la Produce Association | paraltra probablementlundi et å encroire les réponses reçues de l'intérieur, il ne saurait guère dire antre chose que la plante adēji gagné une partie du retard, qu'elle est saine, que les vers brillent jusqu'ici pas leur absence et que l'eau est suffisante partout.. | . Le marché du disponible a été plus actif que par le passé et il n'a été arrêté dans son essor que par la pénurie de la marchandise en yente. En tous cas, pour ce qui est des prix, il 1 y a de la hausse et elle consiste en 1/4 de

tallari sur toute la ligne. Le fully good fair cependant est difficile à trouver, même à la cote officielle. | Les exportations de la semaine ont dépassé les prévisions avec leur total de 8.500 balles, contre 9.500 en 1906 pour la même période. Mais ce qui est plus sutisfaisant encore, c'est que les pronostics pour la semaine prochaine sont favorables: on parle deja de 10.000 balles, sinon davantage, contre 4.800 pour la période

correspondante de l'année dernière. 1 Ces augmentations ne doivent toutefois pas nous surprendre, car il est de fait que les nonvelles affaires concluies depuis quelqnes jours ne sont pas à dédaignér. Nos exportateurs mêmes l'admettent et chez certains, il y A même la croyance que leur importance. nous

vaudra un déport marqué sur Novembre. Ceci I ne serait du reste qu'ume conséquence naturel Ile de la meilleure demande surgie de nouveau I pour les, files fins et de la hausse signalée | depuis quelques jours par Manchester.

Liverpool a été assez propice aux égyptiens disponibles comme ventes, relativement aux deux semaines précédentes, bien entendu ; mais pour ce qui est des prix; le cas n'est pas le même. Pour le Spot il n'a fait, après tout, que
revenir au point de départ, soit au cours de | 10 5/16, tandis que, pour les futurs, la hausse est limitée à 4/64, la cote étant de 10 14/64 pour le Juin.
Les Américains disponibles, par contre, ont |été peu actifs, mais comme prix il y a hausse, surtout pour le spot que nous trouyons aujourd'hui à 7.10, soit 30 points de mieux.
Les futurs, pour leur part, avaient avance a peu près dans les mêmes proportions, mais la réaction de ce soir, dont on ignore la cause, quoiqu'on puisse l'attribuer aux réalisations, a
ramené la hausse à 14 points pour le Juillet1 Aont qui, clôture à 6.67 et à 18 points pour
l'Octobre Novembre que nous trouvons à 6.47.

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: En fait de recettes, nous n'avons rien en de saillant on d'extraordinaire, mais quand même nos arrivages ont sufi aux besoins courants de l'exportation. Ainsi, la hausse qye nous avons
å signaler sur les cours du disponible n'est pas à attribuer à une demande exceptionnelle, mais bien et tout simplement à la situation des | contrats. Le dernier cours pratiqué a été de P.T. 90.

Sur le terme, les affaires n'ont pas été Snormes, mais à un moment donné, les choses ont eu l'air de vouloir se corser. En effet, mercredi, une tentative d'écraser les cours a'été faite par un vendeur en blanc: tant qu'il vendait pour I peser, il a trouvé facilement preneur, mais des qu'il a tenté de se racheter, il n'a plus trouvé de centre partie et le seul résultat matériel qu'il a obtenu a dté de voir les cours monter.

comme une fusée de près de 3 piastres en peu | l'instants. C'est un coup rate, mais dont la conséquence a été la fermeté depuis lors et une clôture à PAT. 91 1/2 pour le Juin, soit P.T. 2 de hausse pour la semaine.

Hull s'en tient pour le moment à son cours |dde £8.10-, mais on croit qu'une surprise à la hausse pourrait bien nous venir de là à cause de l'existence de quelques engagements sur les huiles, dont les circonstances rendent l'exécutión presque impossible.

Ce sera une bourrasque, mais qui pourrait bien balayer le restant de nos ressources de la campagne actuelle, d'antant plus que Mar. seille vient de nous acheter un chargement et que pour l'Angleterre même il y aurait de la demande pour out ports.

La nouvelle récolte commence à attirer l'attention de la spéculation, ce qui fait que les 3 mois chez nous sont très fermes à la cote de PT. 72.1/, avec tendance à la bansse. Le prix en lui-inême serait élevé, mais il montera Orement encore, car il n'est pas logique qu'il puisse rester & P.T. 20 au-dessous du disponible avec une entrée en campagne sans rien sous la main à triturer. Les besoins des deux premiers mois, spit Septembre et Octobre, devront être payés chers.
Hull offre £7. 2/6 pour le Novembre Janvier,

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: ' * La physionomie du marché financier ne s'est I pas sensiblement modifiée pendant la huitaine qui vient de s'écouler. Les compartiments des Banques et des Sociétés Foncières restent parmi les plus actifs de la cote, sans que cette | semaine, leurs cours aient subi des modifications bien notables. La liquidation fin demois -- qui s'est jusqu'ici effectuée dans des conditions assez satisfaisantes-- a cependant déter! miné une légère réaction générale, dde aussi en partie au manque d'appui de l'Etranger. Les marchés européens et américains sont malheureusement daus le marasme le plus complet et Lord Rothschild, qui vient de donner son opinion sur la situation générale, semble être I très pessimiste en ce qui concerne l'avenir.

Tout le monde ne partage certainement pas cet avis en Europe, mais un fait est certain c'est qu'il serait impossible, dans les conditions actuelles, de compter sur une amélioration en Europe pour soulager notre place.

Nous estimons que le marché égyptien doit, autant que possible, se rendre indépendant et ce tant par la coalition de ses forces et moyens que par une stricte réglementation de ses Bourses. | Nous sommes heureux de constater que les

très louables efforts déployés dans le but del | dégager la place sont sur le point d'aboutir al des résultats pratiques. Une des conditions essentielles pour donner de l'animation à la Bourse et faire remonter la cote était, sans conteste, le rétablisseinent des opérations à terme qui avaient été précédemment supprimées afin de déjouer les manæuvres des bais.
siers.

Les marchés à terme ayant été remis en vigueur et réglementés judiciersement, on a de suite procédé entre les 35 agences de notre ville à la constitution d'un syndicat de garantie pour les affaires à terme, an capital de 70,000 £.
D'autre part, la formation d'un syndicat d'acheteurs est également un fait accompli a l'heure actuelle. Le capital a été limité à
400.000 L.E. bien que les souscriptions de I passent de beancoup ce chiffre. Il est entendu que si de nonveanx besoins se faisaient sentir, il serait fait un nonvel appel d'au moins | 400,000 LE.

On espère avec raison que, non seulement on n'aura pas besoin de recourir å une augmen tation du capital, mais encore que la première mise sera le moins possible entamée. Il y a en effet beaucoup de personnes parmi les mieux informées qui croient que l'effet moral, d'une part, et de l'autre, l'arrêt forcé de la baisse ad dessous d'une limite infranchissable seront suffisants pour déterminer des achats plus importants qu'on ne pense et permettre de gagner Septembre sans avoir à déplorer aucune défaillance, pas plus dans le monde de Ila Bourse que dans le commerce. | L'Assemblée tenue au Caire a nommé trois délégués : MM. Harari Pacha, M. Cattavi bey et Elie Curiel, qui, joints aux trois délégués d'Alexandrie, MM. Jacques de Menasce, G. Zervudachi et Joseph Aghion formeront le comité chargé des intérêts du syndicat

Ce Comité sera juge des achats à faire. Il est à espérer qu'il se défiera soigneusement de certains titres en vogue avant la debacle pour ne s'occuper que de ceux qui présentent des garanties sérieuses. Les ordres seront remis à la Banque Nationale, qui est chargée par les autres établissements de Crédit adhérents de -centraliser les fonds qu'ils avancent sur les titres déposés par les membres du syndicat
la marge convenue pour ces avances est de 25% et le taux d'intérêt a été fixé 1 6 des sommes avancées.
Grace à ces sages mesures, il est permis d'envisager l'avenir sous un jour moins sombre

et d'espérer une reprise. Les financiers du Caire et d'Alexandrie qui ont pris si à coeur l'intérêt du pays ont droit à la reconnaissance publique. | La première Assemblée Générale des Actionnaires de l'Egyptian Auto Transport Company s'est tenue au siège social, 86, rue du Mex, le 26 mai courant. Plus de 1200 actions y étaient représentées. L'Assemblée. A ap: | prouvé, à l'unanimité, le Bilan , et les
somptes de ce premier Exercice 1905, com pose d'une courte période de quelques mois seulement
Ce laps de temps, fort restreint, a été acti| vement employé pour l'organisation de l'en

treprise et l'installation d'un matériel indus(triel, fixe et roulant, de tout premier ordre, dans la propriété, près du Gabbari, acquise dans des conditions avantageuses, lesquelles ont, actuellement, pour conséquence, le mérite | appréciable d'une importante plus-value en

faveur de la Société. | Ce "Boni" couvre et de beaucoup les frais de "Premier Etablissement" qui, cependant, ne sont amortissables qu'en cinq annnités. Il I permet aussi d'affirmer qu'au 31 décembre | 1906, le Capital de le Société, malgré les dits | | frais ineluctables, était absolument intact et i représentait bien, sans aucun déchet, celui-|souscrit lors de sa constitution.

Cette première période d'installation et de tudes pratiques étant terminée, l'Entreprise est supérieurement outillée. Elle va dono pouvoir consacrer ses efforts actifs à l'exploitation da transport des marchandises, principal objot! et but de sa fondation, au moyen de l'ingt Camions Automobiles, 21 30 H.C. d'one por tée utile de cinq tonnes chacun, marchant à raison de 10 kilometres par beure.

Ce sera, pour la Société, l'on verture de la période féconde de prospérité. Le sueeès en est assuré par les négociations, déjà engagées et sur le point d'aboutir à des contrats, avec d'importantes maisons de commerce, d'importation et d'exportation, de notre place, les quelles obtiendront, à des prix éganx et même inférieurs, des avantages de célérité et d'exonération d'avarie que le charroi à tráction animale ne peut absolument pas leur donner,

En outre da Serviee des "Transports" la Société va entreprendre la réparation des Automobiles privés et la charge d'Acoumulateurs, ce qui lui constituera une seconde branche de revenu et lui donnera toujours un appoint

La parfaite installation des Ateliers et leur complet ontillage permettra, facilement et bien, l'exécution de ces travaux de réparations accomplis exclusivement par des Mécaniciens spécialistes français.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Vendredi 31 Mai 1907. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres & encore baissé hier de 1/8 à 3 1/2 pour cent

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a avancé de 1/8 à 84 5,8. L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 100 1/4. La National Bank A ré trograde de 1/40 22 1/2. La Daira Sanieh et la Delta Light ont, d'autre part, perdu 1/8 å 15 et à 9.3,4. L'Agricole s'est maintenue & 8 1/2.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a reculé de 3 franca å 705. La Banque d'Athènes A • perdu 1 franc à 128.

Ici, le début de la séance a été calme, avec une certaine tendance à la lourdear. On remarquait tout de même que, si les offres étaient abondantes, elles trouvaient plus aisément qu'hier une contre partie. Peu apres, une certaine animation s'est manifestée, qui n'a pas tardé à se traduire en une bonne reprise. Ce revirement est, certes, då d'une part à la bonne tenue du coton et d'autre part au fait que la liquidation s'est terminée heureusement ce matin à Alexandrie, après avoir déterminé avant-hier et hier l'allegernent de situations fortement chargées.
La National Bank, que ndais avions laissée hier à 22 1/2, a atteint 22 3/4, soit en reprise de 1/4 do livre. L'Agricole s'est raffermie à 8 3/8 La Banque d'Orient a progressé à 122.123.
Lo Crédit Foncier a été délaissé à 705 ; l'obligation à lots nouvelle a reculé à 262
Les New Egyptian ont été mieux tenus à 18 sh.-18 sh. 3. Les Markets sont revenus à 23 sh 3. et les Walker and Meimarachi £03/87/16.
Très demande, la part de fondateur Epargne Immobilière Ltd., a passéde PE 66 à 80.

Il y a eu beaucoup d'affaires en titros sur lesquels le marché n'a pas été encore rendo libre. Les transsetions ont porté principale. ment sur les Estates 1 5/16, les Delta Land à 2 1/4-5/16, les Egyptian Hotels à 6 3/4, les Nungovich à 18, les Allotments à 2 1/8, etc
Lo brait a couru ce matin en Bourse que le Crédit Lyonnais et le Comptoir National d'E, compte de Paris avaient fini par adhérer au syndicat constitué pour soutenir les valeurs égyptiennes.

Or, nous croyons savoir que cette information est inexacte. La vérité est que ces établissements de crédit refusent toujours de don ner leur mhésion, quils considéreraient comme contraire à leurs statuts , ils sont prêts, en retour, à accorder des facilités au commerce français en Egypte pour l'aider à traverser la crise actuelle.
Le marché des valeurs étant fermé les samedis pendant la saison d'été, le prochain numéro de notre Circulaire paraîtra le lundi 3 Juin.

Dans son numéro d'hier, "-L'Imparziale" fait très judicieusement observer que la tâche du syndicat formé pour soutenir des valeurs égyptiennes est difficile et ingrate, car leopmite de ce consortium devral se défendre contre des influences et des préoccupations étrangères à la place.

" Il y a des valeurs, dit "L'Imparziale", qui ont un marché assez vaste pour y puiser Pelasticité suffisante à réagir contre la baisse : telles sont, par exemple, la National Bank, PAgricole, la Daira, etc. D'autre part, des achats considérables sur ces titres en Egypte pourraient donner lieu à des arbitrages dont la conséquetice serait d'absorber de l'argent égyptien pour acheter des titres à l'étranger. D'autres valeurs, comme le Crédit Foncier, de peuvent être soutenues ici puisque leur principal marché estas Paris.

"Les valeurs qui ont besoin d'être encouragées et qui peuvent l'être avec un effort très léger sont les valeurs purement locales de pre mier ordre, qui n'étant négociées qu'en Egypte, pèsent lourdement sur le marché et se trouvent aujourd'hui très au-dessous de leur valeur in trinsèque. Lorsque le cauchemar du flottant sera écarté pour ces titres, toute la cote s'en ressentirs, à commencer par les valeurs de premier ordre
L'assemblée générale extraordinaire de la Société Générale Egyptienne pour l'Agricul. ture et le Commerce, n'ayant pu otre tenue;.
faute de quorum, le 21 Mai courant, les action *naires sont convoqués à nouveau pour le 28 Juin prochain au siège social à Anvers.
A l'ordre du jour: 1°. Confirmation d'apports ; 2°: Augmentation du capital et modifi. cations aux statuts.

Les créanciers de l'Egyptian Cotton Mills Ltd. en liquidation sont priés, d'adresseravant le 31 Août prochain les détails de leurs créan. ces ou de leurs réclamations à MM. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt, liquidateurs de cette sociéts.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les actionnaires de la George Nungovich Hotels Co sont informés que le dividende de l'exercice 1906-1907, fixé à PE, 97 1/2 par action, sera payable à partir du 17 Juin prochain à la Banque de Salonique, au Caire et à Alexandrie, contre remise du coupon No. 8.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de For de l'Etat Egyptien
div.p: AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au 15 Juin 1907, à midi, des offres pour l'achat des figues de barbarie produites le long de la voie ferrée entre Benha at Abou Hammad. **Chaqne sonmissionnaire doit joindre à son offre un récépissé de versement de LE 20 å titre de dépot provisoire.
Les offres seront valables pendant 15 jours Tà partir de la date fixée pour la remise des soumissions.

Chaque offre devra être accompagnée d'une feuille de papier timbré de 30m/m. Elle devra être adressée par la poste sous pli recommandé à : Monsieur le Directe ar General *des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat,

Le Caire. et sous double enveloppe l'intérieure portant la suscription : "Offre pour achat des fignes de barbarie entre Benha et Abon Hammad." | Tonte offre reçue après la date et l'heure cidessas fixées ne sera pas prise en considération.
L'Aduninistration ne s'engage pas à accepter l'offre la plus élevée ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées, et elle se reserve le droit de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le, 29 Mai 1907. 30388-2-1

div.head: Societe Anonyme des Eaux du Caire
div.p: Avis aux Actionnaires
Messieurs, les Actionnaires sont convoqués en Assemblée générale extraordinaire, le Mercredi 5 Juin 1907, a 3 heures 1,2 de relevée, au Siège Social, au Caire.
ORDRE DU JOUR : Proposition de création et d'émission d'aotions de jouissance en angmentation de celles existantes, et par suite, modification de l'art. 13 des statuts.

Pour assister à l'Assemblée, il faut être propriétaire de dix actions au moins et faire le dépôt de ces actions cinq jours avant la réunion au Siège de la Société ou dans l'un des établissements ci-après ou lears sucoursales: le Crédit Lyonnais, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien; la Banque Impériale Ottomane, l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank, la Banque Nationale d'Egypte et | la Bank of Egypt. | Lussemblée générale ne pouvant délibérer | valablement que si la proportion d'actions prévue par les statuts est représentée, Messieurs les Actionnaires sont en conséquence priés de faire le dépôt de toutes leurs actions
Le Caire, le 10 Mai 1907.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
